newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Christmas Hong Kong stocks seen firm but rangebound.
newsitem.headline: Christmas Hong Kong stocks seen firm but rangebound.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks are expected to retain a positive tone in the week ahead but after a year of hefty gains, investors are likely to sit back and enjoy the holiday period leaving stocks to trade narrowly, analysts said.
The Hang Seng index closed at 13,131.41 points on Friday, after posting its biggest point gain since August 1994 with a rise of 284.85 points.
The index rose 2.71 percent last week and is up 30.36 percent this year.
"Hong Kong's performance is already very good so I don't see any need to window dress this year. Everybody is already happy where they are," said Franklin Lam, director of research at HG Asia.
The stock exchange will hold a half-day trading session from 1000/0200 GMT to 1230/0430 GMT on December 24 and the market will be closed on December 25 and December 26.

"During the initial part of next week I think it will still be positive but I think that because of the holiday, trading will be thin with not much movement," said Alex Wong, technical analyst at Dharmala Securities.
Analysts said Hong Kong stocks were likely to remain tied to U.S. markets in the week ahead.
"The Hong Kong stock market is following the U.S. bond market," said Ricky Tam, senior research analyst at Delta Asia Securities.
Wong expected the U.S. long bond yield to continue declining in the near term, giving Hong Kong stocks further room to rise.
"Right now I think in the short term it is positive but as the index approaches the 13,350 level there will be quite good resistance ... " Wong said.
The Hang Seng index registered an all-time high on November 28 at 13,744.30 points.
Timber products processor Ta Fu International Holdings Ltd is due to make its market debut on Friday. The Taiwan-based company offered 168 million new shares at HK$1.01 per share.
